thread.title: Tinder date says photos get uglier if you keep scrolling
thread.title_full: Tinder date says photos get uglier if you keep scrolling | Daily Mail Online

author: Katherine Davison For Daily Mail Australia
title: Tinder date says photos get uglier if you keep scrolling
text:
A woman's quirky Tinder profile has garnered worldwide attention for showcasing her 'awesome' sense of humour.
The profile belonging to Zoe, 19, was spotted by Imgur user justastar and posted online.
'Swiped right for humour,' the poster wrote, sharing a series of images from Zoe's profile.
The profile belonging to Zoe has garnered worldwide attention from people who love the 19-year-old's sense of humour
A shot of her smiling into the camera is followed by her looking glum in Mickey Mouse ears
The first profile picture shows Zoe smiling into the camera, her auburn hair swept over to one side and a pair of black-rimmed glasses perched on her nose.
'Zoe, 29, 11 miles away,' the caption underneath reads.
'My photos get uglier if you keep scrolling,' the Tinder-user goes on to state beneath that.
Following her first picture, Zoe's snaps become less posed and more candid.
A shot of her looking glum in Mickey Mouse ears follows, as does a close-up of the teenager with her mouth wide open.
A final image appears to have been taken from above and shows the teenager posing with what looks to be a bulky black mac on.
This photo showed the Tinder user in close-up, with her mouth open and eyes wide
Match-making site Tinder is well known for giving users the option to swipe right if they like the look of someone - and left if they don't.
Whilst Zoe's message may appear counter-intuitive, those who saw her profile online were quick to sing her praises.
'Pretty girls with comedy do it for me,' one admirer on Imgur wrote.
'A sense of humor can be a really attractive quality,' wrote another fan.
Meanwhile a commenter going by the name Milesonacar, agreed with them.
'Date her now! Don't let the one with an actual personality get away,' they wrote.
A final image appears to have been taken from above and shows the teenager posing with what looks to be a bulky black mac on
Last year, a study by the University of Zurich found that playfulness came high on the list of desirable attributes in a long-term partner.
Experts said that a sense of fun was more important to many people than whether someone had a degree or was religious.
The research that playfulness was important to both sexes â€“ just behind friendliness, intelligence and a sense of humour.
They also found that naturally playful people deemed humour, a laid back attitude and creativity more important in partners than their more serious peers.
